A object that indicates the file name.

Optional object to use for handling #include directives. If this value is null, #include directives are either honored when compiling from a file, or cause an error when compiled from a resource or memory.

A string of effect parameters that will be ignored by the effect system. The string must be NULL terminated and needs to contain the name of each application-managed constant separated by a semicolon.
One or more compile options identified by the enumeration.
An object to use for shared parameters. If this value is null, no parameters are shared.
member.returns: An that contains the compiled effect.

member.returns: Radius of the returned bounding sphere.

member.summary: Performs tangent frame computations on a mesh. Tangent, binormal, and optionally normal vectors are generated. Singularities are handled as required by grouping edges and splitting vertices.
member.param: Input mesh object.
Specifies the name of the semantic declaration to use for reading texture coordinates, typically .
If a mesh has multiple texture coordinates, specifies the texture coordinate to use for the tangent frame computations. If zero, the mesh has only a single texture coordinate.
Specifies the type, typically , that describes where the partial derivative with respect to the u texture coordinate will be stored.
Specifies the semantic index at which to store the partial derivative with respect to the u texture coordinate.
Specifies the type, typically , that describes where the partial derivative with respect to the v texture coordinate will be stored.
Specifies the semantic index at which to store the partial derivative with respect to the v texture coordinate.
Specifies the type, typically , that describes where the normal vector at each vertex will be stored.
Specifies the semantic index at which to store the normal vector at each vertex.

Combination of one or more values that specify tangent frame computation options. If zero, the following options will be specified: & !( WeightByArea | WeightEqual | OrthogonalizeFromU | OrthogonalizeFromV | WrapUV | DontNormalizePartials | WindClockwise | CalculateNormals ).
object that represents an array of three values per face that specify the three neighbors for each face in the mesh.

Specifies the maximum cosine of the angle at which two partial derivatives are deemed to be incompatible with each other. If the dot product of the direction of the two partial derivatives in adjacent triangles is less than or equal to this threshold, then the vertices shared between these triangles will be split.

Specifies the maximum magnitude of a partial derivative at which a vertex will be deemed singular. As multiple triangles are incident on a point that have nearby tangent frames, but altogether cancel each other out (such as at the top of a sphere), the magnitude of the partial derivative will decrease. If the magnitude is less than or equal to this threshold, then the vertex will be split for every triangle that contains it.

Similar to , specifies the maximum cosine of the angle between two normals that is a threshold beyond which vertices shared between triangles will be split. If the dot product of the two normals is less than the threshold, the shared vertices will be split, forming a hard edge between neighboring triangles. If the dot product is more than the threshold, neighboring triangles will have their normals interpolated.
Output object that receives a mapping of new vertices computed by this method to the original vertices.
member.returns: Output mesh object that receives the computed tangent, binormal, and normal vector data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh.ComputeTangentFrame(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions)
member.summary: Performs tangent frame computations on a mesh. Tangent, binormal, and optionally normal vectors are generated. Singularities are handled as required by grouping edges and splitting vertices.
member.param: Combination of one or more values that specify tangent frame computation options. If zero, the following options will be specified: & ( GenerateInPlace | ( !( WeightByArea | WeightEqual | OrthogonalizeFromU | OrthogonalizeFromV | WrapUV | DontNormalizePartials | WindClockwise | CalculateNormals ) ).

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh.Optimize(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.MeshFlags,Microsoft.DirectX.GraphicsStream)
member.summary: Controls the reordering of mesh faces and vertices to optimize performance and generate an output mesh.
member.param: Type of optimization to perform; can be set to one or more flags (except , , and ).
A containing three values per face that specify the three neighbors for each face in the source mesh. If the edge has no adjacent faces, the value is 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh.Optimize(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.MeshFlags,Microsoft.DirectX.GraphicsStream,System.Int32[]@,System.Int32[]@,Microsoft.DirectX.GraphicsStream@)

A containing three values per face that specify the three neighbors for each face in the source mesh. If the edge has no adjacent faces, the value is 0.

[in, out] Array for the face adjacency array of the optimized mesh. The face adjacency is stored as an array of arrays. The innermost array is three indices of adjacent triangles, and the outermost array is one set of face adjacencies per triangle in the mesh.
[in, out] Destination buffer that contains the new index for each face.
A that contains the new index for each vertex.
member.returns: A object that represents the optimized mesh.

member.summary: Performs adaptive tessellation based on the z-based adaptive tessellation criterion.
member.param: Specifies a 4-D vector () that is dotted with the vertices to get the per-vertex adaptive tessellation amount. Each edge is tessellated to the average value of the tessellation levels for the two vertices it connects.
Maximum limit for adaptive tessellation. This is the number of vertices introduced between existing vertices. The range of this integer value is between and 32.
Minimum limit for adaptive tessellation. This is the number of vertices introduced between existing vertices. The range of this integer value is between 1 and .
Resulting tessellated mesh. For more information, see .

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ProgressiveMesh.Optimize(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.MeshFlags,System.Int32[]@,System.Int32[]@)
member.summary: Generates an output mesh with reordered faces and vertices to optimize performance.
member.param: Type of optimization to perform. This parameter can be set to one or more flags from (except , , , , or ).

Array for the face adjacency array of the optimized mesh. The face adjacency is stored as an array of arrays. The innermost array is three indices of adjacent triangles, and the outermost array is one set of face adjacencies per triangle in the mesh. The size of this array is the maximum number of faces multiplied by 3.
Array that contains the new index for each face.
member.returns: A object that represents the optimized mesh.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Width of the texture, in pixels
Height of the texture, in pixels.

Number of coefficients per sample location. When using spherical harmonic (SH)precomputed radiance transfer (PRT), the number of coefficients should be Order2, where Order is the order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Order must be in the range of to , inclusive. The degree of the evaluation is Order - 1.
Number of color channels to set in the mesh. Set to 1 to specify gray materials (R = G = B), or 3 to enable color bleeding effects.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine
member.summary: The class is used to compute a precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) simulation. Its methods are typically used offline to compute per-vertex or per-texel transfer vectors in advance of real-time 3-D modeling.

member.name: E:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.Disposing
member.summary: Occurs when the method is called or when the object is finalized and collected by the garbage collector of the Microsoft .NETcommon language runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ClosestRayIntersects(Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3,Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.IntersectInformation@)
member.summary: Uses efficient ray-tracing in precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) simulations to determine whether a ray intersects a mesh. If an intersection is found, the method returns the index of the closest mesh face hit by the ray and the barycentric coordinates of the intersection point.
member.param: A structure that specifies the point where the ray begins.
A structure that specifies the direction of the ray.
An structure that represents the intersection point and the current mesh face that is first hit by the given ray, based upon stacking all blocker mesh faces in front of the current mesh.
member.returns: true if the ray intersects the current mesh; false if it does not.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeBounce(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes the source radiance resulting from a single bounce of interreflected light. This method can be used for any lit scene, including a spherical harmonic (SH)-based precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) model.
member.param: A object that represents the 3-D object from the previous light bounce. This input buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that models a single bounce of the interreflected light. This output buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that is the running sum of all previous outputs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeBounceAdaptive(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes the source radiance resulting from a single bounce of interreflected light, using adaptive sampling. This method generates new vertices and faces on the mesh to more accurately approximate the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) signal. This method can be used for any lit scene, including a spherical harmonic (SH)-based precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) model.
member.param: A object that represents the 3-D object from the previous light bounce. This input buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
Threshold on the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) vector to use for subdividing mesh vertices and faces. If less than 1e-6f, a default value of 1e-6f is specified.

Minimum face edge length that will be generated in adaptive sampling. If the method determines that the value is too small, a model-dependent value is specified. If zero, a default value of 4 is specified.
Maximum level of subdivision of a face that will be used in adaptive sampling.
A object that models a single bounce of the interreflected light. This output buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that is the running sum of all previous outputs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeDirectLightingSphericalHarmonics(System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes the direct-lighting contribution to 3-D objects where the source radiance is represented by a spherical harmonic (SH) approximation.
member.param: Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The evaluation generates 2 coefficients. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
A object that models the direct lighting contribution with the spherical harmonic (SH) approximation. This buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeDirectLightingSphericalHarmonicsAdaptive(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes the direct-lighting contribution to 3-D objects where the source radiance is represented by a spherical harmonic (SH) approximation, using adaptive sampling. This method generates new vertices and faces on the mesh to more accurately approximate the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) signal.
member.param: Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The evaluation generates 2 coefficients. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
Threshold on the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) vector to use for subdividing mesh vertices and faces. If less than 1e-6f, a default value of 1e-6f is specified.

Minimum face edge length that will be generated in adaptive sampling. If the method determines that the value is too small, a model-dependent value is specified. If zero, a default value of 4 is specified.
Maximum level of subdivision of a face that will be used in adaptive sampling.
A object that contains the output data. This buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeDirectLightingSphericalHarmonicsGpu(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Device,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Uses the graphics processing unit (GPU) to compute the direct-lighting contribution to 3-D objects where the source radiance is represented by a spherical harmonic (SH) approximation. Computing the lighting on the graphics processing unit (GPU) will generally be much faster than on the CPU.
member.param: The used to run the simulation on the graphics processing unit (GPU). The device must support pixel shader version 2.0 or higher.

The graphics processing unit (GPU) simulation parameter that defines the resolution of the shadow z-buffer. Should be set to one of the enumeration values. To specifiy higher precision simulation, the value may be combined with one of the values.
Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The evaluation generates 2 coefficients. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
Bias in the normal direction.
Bias in the normal direction, scaled by one minus the cosine of the angle with the light ray.
A object that contains the output data. This buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeLDPrtCoefficients(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes locally-deformable precomputed radiance transfer (LDPRT) coefficients relative to per-sample normal vectors to minimize the least-squares error with respect to input data. These coefficients can be used with skinned or transformed normal vectors to model global effects on dynamic objects.
member.param: A object that represents the spherical harmonic (SH)precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) data.
Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The evaluation generates 2 coefficients. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.

A array to be filled with shader-optimal normal vectors for which locally-deformable precomputed radiance transfer (LDPRT) coefficients are optimized. This array must be the same size as the number of samples in .
A object that contains zonal harmonic coefficients per color channel per sample.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeSubsurfaceScattering(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes the source radiance resulting from subsurface scattering, using material properties set by . This method can be used only for materials defined per-vertex in a mesh object.
member.param: A object that represents the 3-D object from the previous light bounce. This input buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that models a single bounce of the subsurface-scattered light. This output buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that is the running sum of all previous outputs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeSubsurfaceScatteringAdaptive(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes a transfer vector that maps source radiance to exit radiance resulting from subsurface scattering, using adaptive sampling and material properties set by . The method generates new vertices and faces on the mesh to more accurately approximate the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) signal. This method can be used only for materials defined per-vertex in a mesh object.
member.param: A object that represents the 3-D object from the previous light bounce. This input buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
Threshold on the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) vector to use for subdividing mesh vertices and faces. If less than 1e-6f, a default value of 1e-6f is specified.
Minimum face edge length that will be generated in adaptive sampling. If the method determines that the value is too small, a model-dependent value is specified.
Maximum level of subdivision of a face that will be used in adaptive sampling. If zero, a default value of 4 is specified.
A object that models a single bounce of the subsurface-scattered light. This output buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that is the running sum of all previous outputs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeSuperClusters(System.Int32[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Used with compressed results of the vertex version of the precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) simulator. Generates "superclusters," which are groups of clusters that can be drawn in the same draw call. A greedy algorithm that minimizes overdraw is used to group the clusters.
member.param: An array of cluster identifiers (IDs) extracted from a compressed buffer by calling .
A that represents the composite scene passed to the simulator.
Maximum number of clusters allocated per super cluster.
An integer array that contains the index of the super cluster to which the corresponding cluster was assigned.
member.returns: Number of super clusters allocated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeSurfSamplesBounce(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) samples for an arbitrary point (and normal vector).
member.param: A object that represents the 3-D object from the previous light bounce. This input buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
Number of sample locations.
Position for each sample.

A object that models the direct lighting contribution to the point, using the spherical harmonic (SH) approximation. This output buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
A object that is the running sum of all previous outputs.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeSurfSamplesDirectSphericalHarmonics(System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes, at an arbitrary point not on a mesh, a transfer vector that maps source radiance (represented by a spherical harmonic (SH) approximation) to exit radiance.
member.param: Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The evaluation generates 2 coefficients. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
Position for each sample.
Normal vector for each sample location.
Output object that models the direct lighting contribution to the point, using the spherical harmonic (SH) approximation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeVolumeSamples(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes a projection of the direct lighting from the previous light bounce into spherical harmonic (SH) basis vectors that represent incident radiance at specified locations.
member.param: A object that represents the 3-D object from the previous light bounce. This buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.
Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) evaluation. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The evaluation generates 2 coefficients. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
An integer array that contains the position for each sample.

A object that projects the direct lighting from the previous light bounce into spherical harmonic (SH) basis vectors. This buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtEngine.ComputeVolumeSamplesDirectSphericalHarmonics(System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Vector3[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Computes a projection of distant lighting into spherical harmonic (SH) basis vectors that represent incident radiance at specified locations.
member.param: Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) representation of distant lighting. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
Order of the spherical harmonic (SH) representation of local lighting. Must be in the range of to , inclusive. The degree of the evaluation is - 1.
An integer array that contains the position for each sample.

A object that projects the distant lighting into spherical harmonic (SH) basis vectors. This buffer must have the proper number of color channels allocated for the simulation. This method generates 2 * 2 scalars per channel at each sample location.

member.summary: Sets mesh material properties in the 3-D scene. Use this method to specify subsurface scattering parameters.
member.param: An array of structures that contain the mesh material properties to set.

Number of color channels to set in the mesh. Set to 1 to specify gray materials (R = G = B), or 3 to enable color bleeding effects. If you intend to change this parameter, first set the albedo using another method such as or .

Set to true to set the albedo of the mesh to , overwriting all existing texel and vertex albedo values. Set to false to preserve all existing texel and vertex albedo values set by other methods; must match the parameter of the constructor used to create the buffer.
Scale of the 3-D scene relative to a 1 mm cube. Used for subsurface scattering computations.

Maximum intersection distance. If 0.0f, the previous value will be used; otherwise, must be greater than .

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.RenderToEnvironmentMap
member.summary: Generalizes the process of rendering to environment maps. This class supports the creation of surfaces for the following kinds of geometry: cube, half sphere or hemispheric, parabolic, and sphere.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class.

A object that contains an array of values that represent vertex weights. If this parameter is omitted, all vertex weights are set to 1.0. Note that the higher the vertex weight is for a given vertex, the less likely it is to be simplified away.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SurfaceLoader.FromFile(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Surface,System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.String,System.Drawing.Rectangle,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ImageInformation@)
member.summary: Loads a surface from a file.
member.param: A object that represents the destination surface.
A object that represents the destination rectangle.
String that contains the source file name.
A object that represents the source rectangle.
One or more members of the enumeration that control how the image is filtered.

Integer value that represents the color to replace with transparent black, or 0 to disable the . This value is always a 32-bit ARGB color, regardless of the source image format. alpha is significant and should usually be set to 0xFF for opaque color keys. Thus, for opaque black, the value is equal to 0xFF000000.
[ref] An structure that represents the source image information.

This value is always a 32-bit ARGB color, regardless of the source image format. alpha is significant and should usually be set to 0xFF for opaque color keys. Thus, for opaque black, the value is equal to 0xFF000000.
[ref] An structure that represents the source image information.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TextureGutterHelper
member.summary: Used to build and manage gutter regions in a texture. Gutter regions separate textures and allow for bilinear interpolation to avoid rendering artifacts at texture boundaries.

member.name: E:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TextureGutterHelper.Disposing
member.summary: Occurs when the method is called or when the object is finalized and collected by the garbage collector of the Microsoft .NETcommon language runtime.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TextureGutterHelper.ApplyGutters(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PrtBuffer)
member.summary: Applies gutters to a texture object.
member.param: A object to add gutters to.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TextureGutterHelper.ApplyGutters(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Texture)
member.summary: Applies gutters to a texture object.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TextureLoader.FilterTexture(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.BaseTexture,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PaletteEntry[]@,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter)
member.summary: Filters mipmap levels of a texture.
member.param: A object that represents the texture object to filter.

Array of structures that represent a 256-color palette to fill in. For formats that are not palletized, use 0. If a palette is not specified, the default Microsoft Direct3D palette (an all-opaque white palette) is provided. See Remarks.
Level whose image is used to generate subsequent levels. A common value for this parameter is 0.
One or more values that control how the mipmap is filtered.

member.summary: Creates a cube texture from a file.
member.param: A object that represents the device to associate with the cube texture.
String that specifies the file name.
Width and height of the cube texture, in pixels. For example, if the cube texture is an 8-pixel by 8-pixel cube, the value is 8. If the value is 0, the dimensions are taken from the file.
Number of mip levels requested. If this value is 0, a complete mipmap chain is created.

Zero or , or . Setting this flag to indicates that the surface should be used as a render target. The resource can then be passed to the parameter of the method. If is specified, the application should determine whether the device supports this operation by calling . The value indicates that the surface should be handled dynamically.

Member of the enumerated type that describes the requested pixel format for the cube texture. The returned cube texture might have a different format from that specified by . Applications should check the format of the returned cube texture. If is , the format is taken from the file.
Member of the enumerated type that describes the memory class into which the cube texture should be placed.
One or more flags that control how the image is filtered.
One or more flags that control how the mipmaps are filtered.

An value to replace with transparent black, or 0 to disable the color key. This value is always a 32-bit ARGB color that is independent of the source image format. Alpha is significant, and usually should be set to FF for opaque color keys. For example, for opaque black, the value equals 0xFF000000.
member.returns: A object that represents the created cube texture object.

Size of the file in memory, in bytes.
Width and height of the cube texture in pixels. For example, if the cube texture is an 8-pixel by 8-pixel cube, the value is 8. If the value is 0, the dimensions are taken from the file.
Number of mip levels requested. If this value is 0, a complete mipmap chain is created.

Zero or , or . Setting this flag to indicates that the surface should be used as a render target. The resource can then be passed to the parameter of the method. If is specified, the application should determine whether the device supports this operation by calling . The value indicates that the surface should be handled dynamically.

Member of the enumerated type that describes the requested pixel format for the cube texture. The returned cube texture might have a different format from that specified by . Applications should check the format of the returned cube texture. If is , the format is taken from the file.
Member of the enumerated type that describes the memory class into which the cube texture should be placed.
One or more flags that control how the image is filtered.
One or more flags that control how the mipmaps are filtered.

An value to replace with transparent black, or 0 to disable the color key. The color key is always a 32-bit ARGB color that is independent of the source image format. Alpha is significant, and usually should be set to FF for opaque color keys. For example, for opaque black, the value equals 0xFF000000.
[in, out] An structure that contains a description of the data in the source image file, or 0.
Array of structures that represent a 256-color palette to fill in, or 0.
member.returns: A object that represents the created cube texture object.

member.returns: Address of a pointer to a object that represents the created texture object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.UVAtlas
member.summary: Contains methods for creating UV texture atlases.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.UVAtlas.Create(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Single[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PercentageCompleteCallback,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates one or more UV texture atlases.
member.param: Input mesh used to calculate the atlas. The atlas must have a position channel and at least a 2-D texture channel.
The maximum number of charts required for the atlas. If this is 0, the atlas will be parameterized based solely on stretch.
The maximum stretch resulting from the atlasing algorithm. 0 means do not stretch; 1 means any amount of stretching is allowed.
The width of the texture the atlas will be used on.
The height of the texture the atlas will be used on.

The minimum distance, in texels between two charts on the atlas. The gutter is scaled by the width. For example, if a gutter of 2.5 is used on a 512x512 texture, then the minimum distance between two charts (in texels) will be 2.5 / 512.0 in uv space.
Specifies which texture coordinate to write to in the output mesh (which is cloned from the input mesh). Useful if your vertex has multiple texture coordinates.
An array with 3 Int32s per face, indicating which triangles are adjacent to each other.
An array with 3 floating-point values per face, describing the integrated metric tensor for that face. See remarks.
A callback function that can be used to monitor progress.
How often the callback specified by will be used. Use 0.0001f as a default value.
member.returns: Contains data about the created texture atlases.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.UVAtlas.Create(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.GraphicsStream,System.Single[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PercentageCompleteCallback,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates one or more UV texture atlases.
member.param: Input mesh used to calculate the atlas. The atlas must have a position channel and at least a 2-D texture channel.
The maximum number of charts required for the atlas. If this is 0, the atlas will be parameterized based solely on stretch.
The maximum stretch resulting from the atlasing algorithm. 0 means do not stretch; 1 means any amount of stretching is allowed.
The width of the texture the atlas will be used on.
The height of the texture the atlas will be used on.

The minimum distance, in texels between two charts on the atlas. The gutter is scaled by the width. For example, if a gutter of 2.5 is used on a 512x512 texture, then the minimum distance between two charts (in texels) will be 2.5 / 512.0 in uv space.
Specifies which texture coordinate to write to in the output mesh (which is cloned from the input mesh). Useful if your vertex has multiple texture coordinates.
A that indicates which triangles are adjacent to each other.
An array with 3 floating-point values per face, describing the integrated metric tensor for that face. See remarks.
A callback function that can be used to monitor progress.
How often the callback specified by will be used. Use 0.0001f as a default value.
member.returns: Contains data about the created texture atlases.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.UVAtlas.Pack(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PercentageCompleteCallback,System.Single,Microsoft.DirectX.GraphicsStream)
member.summary: Packs the face partitioning data into a texture atlas.
member.param: Input mesh used to calculate the atlas. The atlas must have a position channel and at least a 2-D texture channel.
The width of the texture the atlas will be used on.
The height of the texture the atlas will be used on.

The minimum distance, in texels between two charts on the atlas. The gutter is scaled by the width. For example, if a gutter of 2.5 is used on a 512x512 texture, then the minimum distance between two charts (in texels) will be 2.5 / 512.0 in UV space.
Specifies which texture coordinate to write to in the output mesh (which is cloned from the input mesh). Useful if your vertex has multiple texture coordinates.
A callback function that can be used to monitor progress.
How often the callback will be called. Use 0.0001f as a default value.
A that contains the final face partitioning data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.UVAtlas.Partition(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Mesh,System.Int32,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Single[],Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.PercentageCompleteCallback,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates one or more UV texture atlases (like .), without performing the final packing step.
member.param: Input mesh used to calculate the atlas. The atlas must have a position channel and at least a 2-D texture channel.
The maximum number of charts required for the atlas. If this is 0, the atlas will be parameterized based solely on stretch.
The maximum stretch resulting from the atlasing algorithm. 0 means do not stretch; 1 means any amount of stretching is allowed.
Specifies which texture coordinate to write to in the output mesh (which is cloned from the input mesh). Useful if your vertex has multiple texture coordinates.
An array with 3 Int32s per face, indicating which triangles are adjacent to each other.
An array with 3 floating-point values per face, describing the integrated metric tensor for that face. See remarks.
A callback function that can be used to monitor progress.
How often the callback specified by will be used. Use 0.0001f as a default value.
member.returns: Contains data about the created texture atlases.

member.summary: Returns a structure from a declaration.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.VertexInformation.GetDeclarationVertexSize(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.VertexElement[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the size of the vertex declaration for a flexible vertex format (FVF).
member.param: Array of structures that represent the vertex shader declaration. The declaration array must end with as the last element (the size of the vertex element array will be one more than the number of actual vertex elements).
Specifies the vertex data stream, in the range from 0 to the maximum number of streams -1.
member.returns: The vertex declaration size, in bytes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.VolumeLoader
member.summary: Contains functions for loading and saving volumes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.VolumeLoader.FromFile(Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Volume,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Box,System.String,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Box,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter,System.Int32,Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ImageInformation@)
member.summary: Loads a volume from a file.
member.param: A object that specifies the destination volume.
A structure that specifies the destination box. Omit this parameter to specify the entire volume.
String that specifies the file name.
A structure that specifies the source box. Omit this parameter to specify the entire volume.
One or more flags that control how the image is filtered.

An value to replace with transparent black, or 0 to disable the color key. This is always a 32-bit ARGB color that is independent of the source image format. Alpha is significant, and usually should be set to FF for opaque color keys. For example, for opaque black, the value is equal to 0xFF000000.
An structure to fill with a description of the data in the source image file, or 0.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.XFileSaveData.AddDataObject(System.Guid,System.String,System.Guid,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Adds a data object as a child of the file data node.
member.param: The globally unique identifier (GUID) representing the data object's template.
The name of the data object to add.
A globally unique identifier (GUID) representing the data object. The data object must have been registered with or . Specify null if the object does not have a globally unique identifier (GUID).
A array representing the buffer containing all required data in the data object.
member.returns: An object representing the file data node to which the data object will be added.

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.XFileSaveData.AddDataReference(System.String,System.Guid)
member.summary: Adds a data reference as a child of this file data node. The data reference points to a file data object.
member.param: The name of the data object to add by reference. Specify null if the data object does not have a name.
The globally unique identifier (GUID) representing the data object to add by reference. If null, a reference will be added that points to the data object with the given .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.CleanType.
member.summary: Merge triangles that share the same vertex indices but have face normals pointing in opposite directions (back-facing triangles). Unless vertex indices are corrected so that the triangles have the same vertex winding order, mesh adjacency data from the two triangles may conflict.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Each pixel is computed by averaging a 2x2(x2) box of pixels from the source image. This filter works only when the dimensions of the destination are half those of the source, as is the case with mipmaps.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Each destination pixel is computed by sampling the nearest pixel from the source image.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Same as specifying | .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Output data is in sRGB (gamma 2.2) color space.

member.summary: Input data is in sRGB (gamma 2.2) color space.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Resulting image must be dithered using a 4x4 ordered dither algorithm.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Resulting image must be dithered using a 4x4 ordered dither algorithm.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Same as specifying the , , and flags. This flag is always used internally for this function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Pixels off the edge of the texture on the w-axis should be mirrored, not wrapped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Pixels off the edge of the texture on the v-axis should be mirrored, not wrapped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Pixels off the edge of the texture on the u-axis should be mirrored, not wrapped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Each pixel in the source image contributes equally to the destination image. This is the slowest of the filters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Bilinear interpolation filtering is used as a texture magnification or minification filter. A weighted average of a 2x2 area of texels surrounding the desired pixel is used. The texture filter to use between mipmap levels is trilinear mipmap interpolation. The rasterizer interpolates pixel color in a linear manner, using the texels of the two nearest textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.Filter.
member.summary: Mipmapping disabled. The rasterizer uses the magnification filter instead.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality
member.summary: Specifies the level of font quality.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Text is rendered using the Microsoft ClearType antialiasing (smoothing) method when possible. The font quality is given more importance than maintaining the text size; thus, the text width can change. When using this mode for measuring and rendering, ensure that the application does not cache any layout information. If it does, remote users who do not have Microsoft ClearType enabled will view different width and metrics.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Microsoft Windows XP: Text is rendered using the Microsoft ClearType antialiasing method when possible. The font quality is given less importance than maintaining the text size.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Microsoft Windows NT 4.0 and later: Font is antialiased, if it supports antialiasing and if its size falls within the accepted range.Windows 95 with Microsoft Plus!, Windows 98/Windows Millennium Edition (Windows Me): The display must be greater than 8-bit color, must be a single plane device, cannot be a palette display, and cannot be part of a multiple-display monitor setup. In addition, a TrueType font must be selected into a screen device context before it is used in a DIBSection (a structure that contains information about a device-independent bitmap); otherwise, antialiasing does not occur.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Windows 95 with Microsoft Plus!, Windows 98/Windows Millennium Edition (Windows Me), Windows NT 4.0 and later: Font is never antialiased.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Font's character quality is given more importance than exact matching of the logical-font attributes. For Windows Graphics Device Interface (GDI) raster fonts, scaling is disabled and the font closest in size is chosen. Although this size might not correspond exactly when is used, the font's quality is high and its appearance is not distorted. Bold, italic, underline, and strikeout fonts are synthesized if necessary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Font's appearance is given less importance than when the value is used. Scaling is enabled for Windows Graphics Device Interface (GDI) raster fonts, which means that more font sizes are available, but their quality might be lower. Bold, italic, underline, and strikeout fonts are synthesized if necessary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.FontQuality.
member.summary: Font's appearance does not matter.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption
member.summary: Describes the resolution of the shadow z-buffer that will be used in precomputed radiance transfer (PRT) direct lighting simulation on the graphics processing unit (GPU). A higher quality z-buffer can also be specified to reduce noise in the results of the direct lighting simulation, although the simulation will be slower.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption.
member.summary: Same as .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption.
member.summary: The simulation is of high precision, regardless of the selected resolution. Setting this value will reduce noise in the results of the direct lighting simulation, although the simulation will be slower. May be combined with one of the other values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption.
member.summary: Highest resolution simulation. A 2048 x 2048 pixel texture is used in the simulation to encode the shadow z-buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption.
member.summary: High resolution simulation. A 1024 x 1024 pixel texture is used in the simulation to encode the shadow z-buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption.
member.summary: Medium resolution simulation. A 512 x 512 pixel texture is used in the simulation to encode the shadow z-buffer. This is the default value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.GpuSimulatorOption.
member.summary: Low resolution simulation. A 256 x 256 pixel texture is used in the simulation to encode the shadow z-buffer.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags
member.summary: Defines the compiler options to use during a shader compilation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Inserts debug file name and line number information during compilation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to use no options during compilation. Value resolves to 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the effect runtime that the effect will never be cloned (i.e. by using the . method). This reduces the memory usage for the effect by eliminating the need to keep a copy of the effect's shaders in memory.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to prefer using flow-control instructions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to avoid using flow-control instructions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Disables preshaders; that is, the compiler will not pull out static expressions for evaluation on the host CPU.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to use software pixel shaders.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to use software vertex shaders.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Indicates to the device that the operation can be performed and the result stored at a lower precision (at least s10e5).

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to pack matrices in column major order (that is, each vector in a single column).

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to pack matrices in row major order (that is, each vector in a single row).

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to skip optimization steps during code generation. This option is valid only when calling .; it is not recommended unless you are trying to isolate a code problem that you suspect originates in the compiler.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.ShaderFlags.
member.summary: Prevents the compiler from validating the generated code against known capabilities and constraints. This option is recommended only when compiling shaders that are known to work (that is, those that have compiled before without this option). Shaders are always validated before they are set to the device.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags
member.summary: Defines flags used to specify sprite rendering options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Enables alpha blending with . set to true (for nonzero alpha). is the source blend state, and is the destination blend state in calls to . The class requires this flag to be set when drawing text.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Sorts sprites by depth in back-to-front order prior to drawing. This option is recommended when drawing transparent sprites of varying depths.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Sorts sprites by depth in front-to-back order prior to drawing. This option is recommended when drawing opaque sprites of varying depths.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Sorts sprites by texture prior to drawing. This option is recommended when drawing non-overlapping sprites of uniform depth; for example, drawing screen-aligned text with .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Rotates each sprite around its center so that it is facing the viewer. . or . must be called first.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Specifies no modification of the world, view, and projection transforms. The transforms currently set to the device are used to transform sprites when the batched sprites are drawn (that is, when . or . is called). If this option is not specified, the world, view, and projection transforms are modified so that sprites are drawn in screen-space coordinates.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Specifies no changes to the device render state when . is called. The device is assumed to be in a valid state to draw vertices when the . property equals 0 and . is set to , , or .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Prevents the device state from being saved or restored when . or . is called.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.SpriteFlags.
member.summary: Resolves the value to 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions
member.summary: Defines settings used for mesh tangent frame computations.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: The results are stored in the original input mesh, and the output mesh is not used.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Compute the per-vertex normal vector for each triangle of the input mesh, and ignore any normal vectors already in the input mesh.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Vertices are ordered in a clockwise direction around each triangle. The computed normal vector direction is therefore inverted 180 degrees from the direction computed using counterclockwise vertex ordering.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Compute a unit-length normal vector for each triangle of the input mesh. Mutually exclusive with .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Weight the direction of the computed per-vertex normal or partial derivative vector according to the areas of triangles attached to that vertex. Mutually exclusive with .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Compute the partial derivative with respect to texture coordinate u independently for each vertex, and then compute the partial derivative with respect to v as the cross product of the normal vector and the partial derivative with respect to u. Mutually exclusive with and .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Compute the partial derivative with respect to texture coordinate v independently for each vertex, and then compute the partial derivative with respect to u as the cross product of the partial derivative with respect to v and the normal vector. Mutually exclusive with and .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Transform texture coordinates to orthogonal Cartesian coordinates. Mutually exclusive with and .

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Do not normalize partial derivatives with respect to texture coordinates. If not normalized, the scale of the partial derivatives is proportional to the scale of the 3-D model divided by the scale of the triangle in (u, v) space. This scale value provides a measure of how much the texture is stretched in a given direction. The resulting vector length is a weighted sum of the lengths of the partial derivatives.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Texture coordinate values in both u and v directions are between 0 and 1. In this case a texture coordinate set will be chosen that minimizes the perimeter of the triangle.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Texture coordinate values in the v direction are between 0 and 1. In this case a texture coordinate set will be chosen that minimizes the perimeter of the triangle.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TangentOptions.
member.summary: Texture coordinate values in the u direction are between 0 and 1. In this case a texture coordinate set will be chosen that minimizes the perimeter of the triangle.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TransitionType
member.summary: Defines the transition style between values of a mesh animation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TransitionType.
member.summary: Ease-in, ease-out spline transition between values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.TransitionType.
member.summary: Linear transition between values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.WeldEpsilonsFlags
member.summary: Defines the options for welding vertices together.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.WeldEpsilonsFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the weld to allow vertices to be modified only, not removed. This flag is valid only if is set. It is useful to modify vertices so that they are equal, but not to allow vertices to be removed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.WeldEpsilonsFlags.
member.summary: Instructs the weld to allow vertices to be modified only, not removed. This flag is valid only if is set. It is useful to modify vertices to be equal, but not to allow vertices to be removed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.WeldEpsilonsFlags.
member.summary: If a given vertex component is within epsilon, instructs the weld to modify partially matched vertices so that both components are equal. If all components are equal, one of the vertices is removed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.DirectX.Direct3D.WeldEpsilonsFlags.
member.summary: Welds all vertices that are marked by adjacency as being overlapping.

member.summary: Loads skin information and mesh data from a Microsoft Direct3D .x file data object.
member.param: An object that represents the Microsoft DirectX file data object to load.
A enumeration that specifies creation options for the mesh.
A object associated with the mesh.
Array of objects loaded from the .x file data object.

An array of structures, where each structure contains a set of structures. Each represents an attribute group in the returned mesh. The data in these structures represent a particular instance of state information used to initialize an effect. For more information, see .
member.returns: A structure that contains the skin and mesh data from the .x file object.

member.param: An object that represents the Microsoft DirectX file data object to load.

A object associated with the mesh.
A object representing an array of three values per face that specify the three neighbors for each face in the mesh.
